Ulico je zgradil Poncij Pilat
Izraelski arheologi odkrili več kot 200 metrov sprehajališča. Kovanci dokazujejo, da so jo zgradili v času Jezusa Kristusa.
05 Nov 2019, 15:06 by E. B.



Vodila je na Tempeljski hrib.



Raziskovalci odkrivajo zanimivo zgodbo sprehajalne poti.


JERUZALEM – Že leta 1894 so se do ulice dokopali britanski arheologi, najnovejše najdbe pa ugotavljajo tudi točen čas izvora: kovanci, ki so jih nedavno našli pod sprehajališčem, dokazujejo, da so pot zgradili v prvih desetletjih našega štetja, torej jo je po vsej verjetnosti naročil sam Poncij Pilat, takratni guverner Judeje.


Raziskovalci odkrivajo zanimivo zgodbo sprehajalne poti.

Poncija Pilata zgodovina bremeni usmrtitve Jezusa Kristusa, čeprav si je razvpito umil roke in izjavil, da ne bo nosil odgovornosti za obsojenčevo kruto usodo, sicer pa ga je v Judeji na položaj postavil takratni rimski cesar Tiberij. Temeljitega izkopavanja so se prvič po odkritju Britancev lotili strokovnjaki z univerze Tel Aviv že pred šestimi leti in do zdaj razodeli 210 metrov od skupno 600 metrov dolge stopničaste in najverjetneje romarske sprehajalne poti, ki je bila široka osem metrov in po dozdajšnjih ugotovitvah izdelana iz visokokakovostnih materialov. Raziskovalcem pa so se med deli zasvetile oči, ko so odkrili kar več kovancev iz obdobja med 17. in 31. letom našega štetja, kar le še potrjuje dejstvo, da je ulica nastala v obdobju vladavine Poncija Pilata. Arheologi domnevajo, da je razkošna in izjemno natančno načrtovana pot, ki vodi na Tempeljski hrib, imela tudi simbolni pomen in velikansko kulturno vrednost v tistem času, ob njej pa naj bi stali prodajalci, trgovci, gostinci in govorniki ter vsak dan v Davidovem mestu pričarali pisano vzdušje.Tako je bilo vse do leta 70, ko so v Jeruzalem prihrumeli Rimljani in ga opustošili; znamenito sprehajališče so zasule ruševine okoliških domov in stavb, med ostanke so se skrili tudi številni kosi orožja.
600metrov je bila dolga razkošna pot.

The street was built by Pontius Pilate
Israeli archeologists discover more than 200 meters of promenade. The coins prove that they built it in the time of Jesus Christ.
05 Nov 2019, 15:06 by E. B.



She headed to Temple Hill.



Researchers discover an interesting story of the walking path.


JERUSALEM - British archaeologists dug into the street as early as 1894, and the most recent finds also identify the exact time of origin: coins recently found under the promenade prove that they built the trail in the first decades of our count, so it is likely commissioned by Pontius Pilate himself, then governor of Judea.


Researchers discover an interesting story of the walking path.

Pontius Pilate's history is burdensome with the execution of Jesus Christ, though he notoriously washed his hands and declared that he would not be held responsible for the convict's cruel fate, or else he had been appointed to the post by the then Roman emperor Tiberius in Judea. For the first time since the discovery of the British, a thorough excavation was undertaken by experts at Tel Aviv University six years ago and has so far revealed 210 meters of a total of 600 meters long, eight meters wide staircase and probably a pilgrimage walkway, made to date with high quality materials. . However, the researchers' eyes lit up as they discovered as many coins from the period between 17 and 31 AD, which is further confirmed by the fact that the street was created during the reign of Pontius Pilate. Archaeologists believe that the sumptuous and extremely carefully planned path leading to the Temple Hill also had symbolic significance and immense cultural value at the time, with vendors, merchants, caterers and speakers standing there and enchanting every day in David's city. colorful atmosphere. That was until the year 70, when the Romans invaded Jerusalem and ravaged it; the famous promenade was strewn with the ruins of surrounding homes and buildings, and many pieces of weapons were hidden among the remains.
600 meters was a long, luxurious journey.
